Factsheet

What does the word Zimbabwean mean?

There are two meanings listed in OED's entry for the word Zimbabwean. See ‘Meaning & use’ for definitions, usage, and quotation evidence.

How common is the word Zimbabwean?

About 0.4occurrences per million words in modern written English

Oct.–Dec. 20174.7Jan.–Mar. 20184.2Apr.–June 20183.8July–Sept. 20183.5Oct.–Dec. 20183.9Jan.–Mar. 20193.5Apr.–June 20193.8July–Sept. 20193.6Oct.–Dec. 20193.7Jan.–Mar. 20203.4Apr.–June 20203.3July–Sept. 20202.9Oct.–Dec. 20202.7Jan.–Mar. 20212.5Apr.–June 20212.8July–Sept. 20212.9Oct.–Dec. 20213.1Jan.–Mar. 20223.1Apr.–June 20223.3July–Sept. 20223.4Oct.–Dec. 20223.4Jan.–Mar. 20233.3

How is the word Zimbabwean pronounced?

British English

zim-BAHB-way-uhn

zim-BAB-way-uhn

U.S. English

zim-BAHB-way-uhn

zim-BAHB-wee-uhn

Where does the word Zimbabwean come from?

The earliest known use of the word Zimbabwean is in the 1960s.

OED's earliest evidence for Zimbabwean is from 1961, in the Economist.

From a proper name, combined with an English element.

Etymons: proper name Zimbabwe, ‑an suffix.

Nearby entries

Etymology

Summary

From a proper name, combined with an English element.

Etymons: proper name Zimbabwe, ‑an suffix.

< Zimbabwe (Shona Zimbabwe), the name of a country in Southern Africa + ‑an suffix (compare ‑ean suffix…

< Zimbabwe (Shona Zimbabwe), the name of a country in Southern Africa + ‑an suffix (compare ‑ean suffix).

Notes

The independent Republic of Zimbabwe was formed in 1980 and comprises the then remaining territory of the former British colony of Rhodesia (see the discussion at Rhodesian adj.2). The name was originally chosen by the nationalist movement around 1960 to denote the prospective country (in e.g. the name of the Zimbabwe National Party, founded in 1961), with reference to the ruined city of Great Zimbabwe (see Zimbabwe n.).

Meaning & use

Quotations

Hide all quotations

Contents

Earlier version

Zimbabwean, n. and a. in OED Second Edition (1989)

adjective

Of, belonging to, or relating to the East African country of Zimbabwe or its inhabitants.

Formerly the self-governing British colony of Southern Rhodesia, Zimbabwe became an independent republic in 1980.

A Zimbabwean politician said..‘We want to be the governors’.

Economist 29 April 453/1

Zimbabwean economic and social historiography.

African Affairs vol. 78 253 (heading)

You are a true Zimbabwean woman.

T. Dangarembga, This Mournable Body (e-book edition)

Of, belonging to, or relating to the East African country of Zambia or its inhabitants.

Of, belonging to, or relating to the East African country of Zimbabwe or its inhabitants.

Of or relating to Botswana.

= Botswanan, adj.

Of or relating to Angola or its inhabitants.

Of or relating to southern Africa or its inhabitants; (now) spec. of or relating to South Africa or its inhabitants.

Of, relating to, or characteristic of the Cape Malays.

Of or relating to the Ciskei, a territory on the south-eastern coast of South Africa, or its inhabitants. Cf. Transkei, n.

Of, belonging to, or relating to the East African country of Zambia or its inhabitants.

Of, belonging to, or relating to the East African country of Zimbabwe or its inhabitants.

Of or relating to Namibia or its inhabitants.

Of or relating to Soweto or its inhabitants; native to or residing in Soweto.

noun

A native or inhabitant of Zimbabwe.

Southern Rhodesian nationalists call themselves ‘Zimbabweans’, after the ruins.

Economist 13 May 660/2

The Zimbabwean thinks it could go down to the wire.

Independent 29 September (Weekend section) 51/7

Millions of Zimbabweans are in the diaspora.

NewsDay (Zimbabwe) (Nexis) 13 January

A native or inhabitant of Angola.

As a modifier. Designating people or things originating from or belonging to Angola in south-western Africa. Cf. Angolan, adj.

In South Africa: a member of the Muslim community of Cape Town and adjoining districts (chiefly descendants of immigrants and slaves from…

A native or inhabitant of southern Africa; (now) spec. a native or inhabitant of South Africa.

A member of a southern African people inhabiting Botswana. Also as adj.

A native Australian or South African bushman.

An inhabitant of Cape Town or of the Cape Peninsula and its environs.

A native or inhabitant of Transkei, a region situated on the east coast of South Africa to the north-east of the River Kei; spec. (under…

= bushman, n. (the word used in Holland, however, is boschjesman).

A native or inhabitant of Natal, or (now) of KwaZulu-Natal.

South African. A Dutch-speaking citizen of the Cape Colony, the Natal or Transvaal (South African) Republics, or the Orange Free State before the…

A native or inhabitant of the Transvaal.

One skilled in living or hunting on the veldt.

A Griqua; (also) an inhabitant of Griqualand East or Griqualand West.

A native or inhabitant of Rhodesia, esp. a white one.

colloquial. A nickname for: (a) An Afrikaner; (b) a Transvaaler.

A dweller in the backveld.

A native or inhabitant of a rural area.

Frequently with capital initial(s). A white inhabitant of Namibia.

A native or inhabitant of Zimbabwe.

A native or inhabitant of Zambia.

= Botswanan, n.

A native or inhabitant of the republic of Botswana.

A native or inhabitant of Namibia.

A native or inhabitant of the Ciskei; spec. (under apartheid) a citizen of the Republic of Ciskei (1981–94) (now historical).

A native or inhabitant of Soweto.

Frequency

Zimbabwean typically occurs about 0.4 times per million words in modern written English.

Zimbabwean is in frequency band 4, which contains words occurring between 0.1 and 1 times per million words in modern written English. More about OED's frequency bands

Frequency data is computed programmatically, and should be regarded as an estimate.

Frequency of Zimbabwean, adj. & n., 1960–2010

* Occurrences per million words in written English

Historical frequency series are derived from Google Books Ngrams (version 2), a data set based on the Google Books corpus of several million books printed in English between 1500 and 2010.

The overall frequency for a given word is calculated by summing frequencies for the main form of the word, any plural or inflected forms, and any major spelling variations.

For sets of homographs (distinct entries that share the same word-form, e.g. mole, n.¹, mole, n.², mole, n.³, etc.), we have estimated the frequency of each homograph entry as a fraction of the total Ngrams frequency for the word-form. This may result in inaccuracies.

Smoothing has been applied to series for lower-frequency words, using a moving-average algorithm. This reduces short-term fluctuations, which may be produced by variability in the content of the Google Books corpus.

Decade Frequency per million words 19600.1719700.2619800.3319900.4620000.5520100.59

Frequency of Zimbabwean, adj. & n., 2017–2023

* Occurrences per million words in written English

Modern frequency series are derived from a corpus of 20 billion words, covering the period from 2017 to the present. The corpus is mainly compiled from online news sources, and covers all major varieties of World English.

Smoothing has been applied to series for lower-frequency words, using a moving-average algorithm. This reduces short-term fluctuations, which may be produced by variability in the content of the corpus.

Entry history for Zimbabwean, adj. & n.

Zimbabwean, adj. & n. was revised in June 2022.

Zimbabwean, adj. & n. was last modified in July 2023.

oed.com is a living text, updated every three months. Modifications may include:

further revisions to definitions, pronunciation, etymology, headwords, variant spellings, quotations, and dates;

new senses, phrases, and quotations.

Revisions and additions of this kind were last incorporated into Zimbabwean, adj. & n. in July 2023.
